David Saff wrote:
> Excellent idea.  If anyone has an "inside connection" t=
o ant, 
> let me know.

I'm an emeritus committer for Ant, and get on well =
with some of the head
honchos. I've volunteered on the Ant mailing list to =
be a conduit
between these two lists, where one is needed, and to do *some*=
 work
involved in writing a JUnit4 Ant task.

One of the things near the to=
p of my priority list is that we don't get
into the current mess again wher=
eby you need to add JUnit's jar file to
Ant's lib directory (or specify -li=
b ...) due to the JUnit task already
being part of the distribution. To be =
honest, I think the JUnit project
should "own" the Ant task more than Ant s=
hould. (I'm not suggesting it
should be part of the normal JUnit distributi=
on, however.) Hopefully
licences shouldn't get in the way of using a lot of=
 the existing JUnit
Ant task and contributing it to a JUnit-owned repositor=
y...

I suspect that a lack of first-class Ant support would be a major
con=
tributing factor to a slow take-up of JUnit4.

As I say, I'm happy to do so=
me of the work, but as we've seen before I'm
not always able to find time t=
o do all I'd like to (parameterised tests
anyone? I'll get back to it some =
day!). This is likely to become worse
in a couple of months when we go from=
 a family of three to a family of
five - but I'm sure I'll find *some* hack=
ing time. In particular I'm
also happy to code review :)

Jon
